name: MCA
mission: To provide religious, social, and educational services to enable the Muslim community to fulfill its responsibilities and contribute to the betterment o...
zakatClaimEvidence: The Muslim Community Association (MCA) explicitly states, "Submit your Zakah request to the Muslim Community Association." and "MCA's core social service is the collection of Zakat and Sadaqah funds to support people in need...". They also have a dedicated "Zakah Request" section on their website under services and mention that "Zakat Al-Fitr will be collected starting March 9th." Furthermore, they have a "Zakah and Relief committee" chartered to facilitate the distribution of Zakah monies. (Source: https://www.mcabayarea.org/donate/)

dimension_explanations.alignment: MCA shows high alignment for Muslim donors as a Zakat-eligible institution addressing urgent religious and cultural needs [5]. Its long-standing presence in the San Francisco Bay Area establishes a significant track record for community support [3][4].
dimension_explanations.impact: The organization's impact is characterized by direct service provision through its weekend school and social service programs [3][4]. However, the impact score remains in the medium range due to a lack of specific data regarding cost-per-beneficiary and third-party verification of program effectiveness [1][2].

baseline_narrative.headline: The Muslim Community Association of San Francisco Bay Area serves as a vital hub for religious, social, and educational services for the regional Muslim community.
strengths: Designated as Zakat-eligible for donors fulfilling religious obligations
Provides a wide range of community services including education and social welfare
Offers diverse giving options including stock donations
baseline_narrative.summary: The Muslim Community Association of San Francisco Bay Area (MCA) provides comprehensive religious and social services designed to enable the community to fulfill its responsibilities and contribute to society [1][3]. The organization manages diverse programs including Zakah distribution, social services, and a weekend Islamic school to support local families [3][5].

strengths.detail: The organization has a long-standing history, having been <cite id="1">founded in 1981</cite> to serve the Bay Area Muslim community.
MCA <cite id="7">accepts Zakat</cite> and directs it to eligible categories such as <cite id="11">fuqara and masakin</cite>.
The organization facilitates various forms of giving, including the ability to <cite id="12">accept stock donations</cite>.

strengths_deep_dive: The Muslim Community Association of San Francisco Bay Area has built a robust infrastructure over four decades since it was <cite id="1">founded in 1981</cite>. By offering a comprehensive suite of programs, from <cite id="4">Social Services</cite> to a <cite id="6">Weekend Islamic School</cite>, it addresses both the spiritual and practical needs of Muslims in <cite id="2">Santa Clara County, CA</cite>. The organization's commitment to transparency is highlighted by its Platinum Seal from Candid, and it actively tracks <cite id="8">4 outcome metrics</cite> to monitor its community impact.
rich_narrative.summary: The Muslim Community Association of San Francisco Bay Area (MCA), <cite id="1">founded in 1981</cite>, serves as a central hub for Muslims in <cite id="2">Santa Clara County, CA</cite>. The organization's mission is to provide <cite id="3">religious, social, and educational services</cite> to help the community fulfill its responsibilities and contribute to society. MCA operates several core programs, including <cite id="4">Social Services</cite>, <cite id="5">Zakah Distribution</cite>, and educational initiatives like the <cite id="6">Weekend Islamic School</cite> and Granada Islamic School. The organization is verified to <cite id="7">accept Zakat</cite> for eligible categories including fuqara (poor) and masakin (needy). While the charity holds a Platinum Seal of Transparency from Candid and tracks <cite id="8">4 outcome metrics</cite>, comprehensive financial breakdown data, such as its <cite id="9">program expense ratio</cite>, is currently unavailable in public filings. Additionally, the organization currently operates with a <cite id="10">board size of 2 members</cite>, which presents an area for governance growth.
